The ability of viruses to antagonize the antiviral response of the host is a common strategy used by pathogens to propagate and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that mediate the antiviral response induced by IFN. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that mediates nuclear import of cargo proteins. We further demonstrate that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to antagonize the IFN response. Our findings unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. These results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to antagonize the host IFN response and may help in the development of new strategies to combat COVID-19. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of plant foods is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in determining the extent to which species partition food resources. We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the survey also reveals substantial heterogeneity in the impact of the crisis. Some businesses are more vulnerable than others, and some are better positioned to weather the crisis. We also find that many small businesses are financially fragile. Finally, we show that the CARES Act is likely to be an important source of funding for small businesses.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean is a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude of this pollution is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the fate of this pollution in the ocean.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection in this model. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be of great importance as there is no treatment available for MSA. Our results also suggest that caspase-1 could be a therapeutic target in synucleinopathies. This is of particular interest as caspase-1 is a protease that is activated in a variety of neurodegenerative disorders. Finally, our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to treat synucleinopathies in general. This is of great importance as no treatment is currently available for any of the different synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the first line of defense against infection and injury. It is a highly specialized cell type that controls vascular function and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. The endothelium is organized into clusters of cells that are specialized to detect specific stimuli. The communication system between cells is poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The results reveal that the endothelial network is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. The findings provide insights into the design of the endothelial network and its role in vascular function. This knowledge is important for understanding the function of the endothelium in health and disease. The findings also have implications for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders, and social anxiety is one of the most prevalent. The mechanisms underlying social anxiety are not fully understood, but it is clear that anxiety is involved in the development of social subordination. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We also show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is due to reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Finally, we demonstrate that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings suggest that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great significance for various applications. However, the design space is restricted by the use of a single material phase and the development of structural patterns. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple material phases. The structures are digitally designed to seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The design space is expanded and the design efficiency is improved. The proposed strategy can be extended to other fields.

This reversal is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of Hb expression in humans. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the transcriptional induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central regulator of lipid metabolism. In contrast, mTORC1 inhibition sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, and this sensitivity is associated with the suppression of SREBP1. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that mTORC1 inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment in combination with ferroptosis-inducing agents. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with heart failure in patients. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism that involves depletion of ER Ca2+. This depletion causes STIM to relocalize to junctions and activate ORAI. LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This mechanism may explain the association of LCCBs with heart failure in patients. Our data may help to develop new strategies for treating hypertension and heart failure. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but not early-seral–associated species. The NWFP also failed to reverse declines of early-seral–associated bird populations on federal land, where early-seral ecosystems were created. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings provide a cautionary tale for policy makers. We need to learn from the past to improve our future policies. This study is a case study of the influence of policy on biodiversity. It is also a case study of the importance of long-term monitoring.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, including lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity. CTLA-4 deletion induced a shift in the balance of Treg cells and Th17 cells, and the disease phenotype was affected by the timing of CTLA-4 deletion. These findings provide insights into the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. They also suggest that CTLA-4 deletion may be a therapeutic strategy for the treatment of autoimmunity. Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin and diversification of beetles remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species, including 89 genes for 521 species representing all major lineages. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, revealing that these genes were key to the Mesozoic diversification of beetles. Our results suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles, resulting in nearly half of all living beetle species. This study provides insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. (Contains figures and tables.) read more

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the population than for the evolution of the individual. This may be a general phenomenon in human culture. We also find that the greater variation participants had access to in the larger populations may have overwhelmed their working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). This may be a general phenomenon in human culture. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and human culture more generally. The present study provides evidence that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). The attenuated brain DA responses were associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as with increased addiction severity and craving. The findings suggest that the reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. The results also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain DA reactivity in the context of methylphenidate, a drug that is widely used to treat attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and other conditions.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language comprehension are also the most predictive of brain responses to sentences in humans. This suggests that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. We also find that model architecture appears to substantially contribute to neural fit. These results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. This approach should be broadly applicable to understanding the brain mechanisms of higher-level cognition. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is not clear whether this success is due to the inherent properties of DL or to the use of unstable algorithms. We show that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This result implies a classification theory of conditions under which one can compute stable NNs with a given accuracy by an algorithm. We introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and accurate. We also prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This work is a step toward understanding the stability of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This failure is attributed to a classic experiment published 45 years ago. The experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of how people fail to understand exponential growth. Here, we discuss the flaws in the experiment’s design and how they led to the erroneous conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We also discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition and the interpretation of scientific evidence.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. The uncultured human pathogen M. lepromatosis is associated with diffuse lepromatous leprosy and Lucio's phenomenon, a reactional state. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is similar to that of M. leprae and has retained the ability to cause peripheral neuropathy. We also show that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the MRCA of M. leprae than is M. leprae, and that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 14 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two pillars of quantum information theory, which is the main field of application of entanglement. The study of the evolution of entanglement is therefore a key step toward a better understanding of quantum information. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in one-dimensional integrable systems can be completely understood in the scaling limit of infinite time. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C. These features make the vaccine suitable for mass vaccination programs. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we use a Bayesian approach to model the spread of plague by a human ectoparasite vector. We find that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is still poorly understood. This study shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is also shaped by the evolution of the number of neurons. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only shaped by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that regulates the dynamics of actin filaments. It does so by binding to actin and by inducing the formation of a cross-linking intermediate. The mechanism by which ADF/cofilin induces cross-linking is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin-induced cross-linking is mechanically driven. We show that the mechanical torque exerted by ADF/cofilin on actin filaments is critical to boost the rate of cross-linking. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to cross-link highly connected actin networks in cells. Our results have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in cell motility and in cancer. They also have implications for understanding the role of mechanical forces in regulating actin dynamics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. The settlement history of Madagascar is contentious, so we used the genomic data to test the hypothesis of a single settlement from Africa or Asia. We find that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the human population of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for understanding the human population of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a form of emotional contagion that occurs without people’s awareness. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, and that this influence is stronger when people are exposed to more emotional content. These findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better health, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds and are not driven by factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, or health outcomes. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. The evolution of larger body size is a defining characteristic of many groups of animals that have colonized the water. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It is able to cause disease by a variety of mechanisms, including the production of toxins and the formation of biofilms. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili for sensing the environment. The pili are used for twitching motility, which is required for surface attachment. The pili are also used as a sensor for the environment, and this sensing is required for the regulation of a large number of genes involved in virulence and biofilm formation. The pili are stretched by the environment, and this mechanical signal is transduced into the cell by a methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like protein. This is the first example of a bacterial mechanochemical sensor. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of bacterial motility and sensing systems. They also have implications for the development of new strategies for controlling P. aeruginosa infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This has led to a substantial contamination of surface waters. However, the consequences of this contamination for aquatic biodiversity are still unknown. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This is of utmost importance for the protection of our aquatic ecosystems and the biodiversity they harbor.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 has raised concerns about the potential for spillover into wildlife and subsequent transmission back to humans. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a common North American cervid. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human transmission is typically low. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study also provides a unique opportunity to understand the role of wildlife in the spread of SARS-CoV-2. (Read more)

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the consequences of building dams, and the solutions that are needed. We find that the industry has been overestimating the benefits and underestimating the costs of dams. We also find that the industry has been ignoring the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins contribute to disease are not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons in the brain are capable of producing a variety of proinflammatory factors, including cytokines, chemokines, and proteases, in response to Aβ. These factors are capable of inducing microglial activation and migration to the site of Aβ deposition. Our results suggest that Aβ-burdened neurons may be a primary source of inflammation in AD, and may play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is not the same as the one that removes the cap from other types of RNAs. This enzyme, which is involved in the degradation of RNA, prefers Np4-capped RNAs as substrates over their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of the enzyme positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. Consequently, a second deprotection step is required to produce the monophosphorylated 5′ terminus needed to stimulate rapid RNA degradation. This study reveals a mechanism for reprogramming gene expression during stress that could have major implications for the regulation of gene expression in bacteria. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that arginine deprivation could be a mechanism involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We demonstrated that arginine deprivation is associated with a decrease in T cell proliferation, a decrease in T cell mitochondrial function, and an increase in the expansion of regulatory T cells and myeloid-derived suppressor cells. We also demonstrated that arginine deprivation is associated with a decrease in T cell arginine metabolism and an increase in citrulline production. We believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and other applications. It is a semiconductor with a wide bandgap, but its electronic properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without defects, by applying tensile strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without melting, by applying compressive strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering. Our findings are also relevant for other wide-bandgap semiconductors.

The role of plant-derived peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is not well understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a unique, highly conserved, and structurally defined NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. The peptide is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen B. cinerea. The peptide also exhibits strong cell wall binding and penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The peptide is effective in spray applications against gray mold disease in tomato and tobacco plants. These results suggest that NCR peptides are promising candidates for development as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the male–female interface in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. We show that the male–female interface is dynamic, with sperm undergoing extensive changes after mating. We also show that female contributions to the sperm proteome are extensive and support sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the male–female interface and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be of interest to the general public. We hope that this work will inspire further research on the male–female interface. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα), but the mechanism of this interaction is not understood. We show that force application switches VWF A1 and GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWD. The mechanism also suggests that VWF A1 and GPIbα are in a conformational equilibrium. This equilibrium is perturbed by force, which may be a mechanism for regulating VWF function. The mechanism may also be relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been difficult to study. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, using a large number of publicly available metagenomic datasets. The results of this study will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. The HSRL is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high spatial and temporal resolution. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI processes. The observations show that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI research.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for decades. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is ∼15 °C, whereas the temperature inferred from protein reconstruction is ∼80 °C. Here, we show that the ancestral environmental temperature of Earth decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies for malaria control. This article is protected by copyright. It is a semiconductor with a wide bandgap, but its electronic properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, with a vanishing bandgap, by applying a strain below a threshold level. We also show that the metallization can be reversed by releasing the strain. This reversible metallization can be used to tailor the properties of diamond. Our findings can be used to design diamond-based devices with desired properties. This work also provides a general framework for exploring the metallization and demetallization of other crystals. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may inform the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus outbreaks. The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to unfold in a tree-like structure, with each word being processed sequentially. However, this assumption has not been tested directly. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a bottom-up parser that merges words into phrases. Our results suggest that the brain may use a merge operation to build syntactic structures from the bottom up. This operation may be a fundamental component of language processing.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is to convert signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the hypothalamus. Lesions of this circuit block the effect of LH stimulation on eating. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer nitrogen fixation in plants is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows for the control of nitrogen fixation in barley, a cereal crop, in response to the plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for transkingdom signaling. The engineered barley line described here will be made available to the community. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been accelerated, and several promising candidates are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. Here we report a strategy to reduce the cost of a subunit vaccine for COVID-19 by engineering the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein. This engineered RBD exhibits high-affinity binding to the human ACE2 receptor, high-yield manufacturability, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD used in current vaccines. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD may provide a cost-effective alternative to current vaccines for global access. (Read less)

The ligand–receptor interaction between secreted small ALKAL proteins and human ALK and related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK) is implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of neural crest-derived tissues. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/LTK and human ALK are able to activate zebrafish LTK and human ALK in vitro. We further show that zebrafish ALK/LTK and human ALK are able to regulate zebrafish iridophore development in vivo. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of ALK/LTK family receptor activation and regulation in vivo. They also suggest that ALKALs may be promising therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague from its progenitor, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, is a well-documented event, but the timing and geographic spread of this process are poorly understood. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y BP. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work is important for understanding the origins and evolution of plague, as well as its spread and impact on human history. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The fate of crop production management practices that aim to increase soil health and mitigate climate change is unclear. We investigated the effects of soil health management practices on soil organic carbon (SOC) storage and distribution between particulate and mineral-associated organic matter in a long-term field experiment. We found that soil health management practices that reduced soil disturbance and incorporated legumes and manure into annual cropping systems increased SOC storage and mineral-associated SOC, but did not significantly increase total SOC storage. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to increase SOC storage on North American agricultural soils. Our findings also suggest that soil health management practices that increase mineral-associated SOC may be more effective at mitigating climate change than practices that increase total SOC storage. This study provides a framework for assessing the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on Mollisols worldwide. Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. One of the most striking features of Nesocodon’s red nectar is that it is produced by a plant that does not depend on animals for reproduction. Here, we show that the red color of Nesocodon’s nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this pigment in other plants. This work suggests that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also demonstrates that the red color of nectar is not a unique visual attractant for pollinators.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 500 and 700 AD. The individuals in our sample exhibit a very high genetic diversity, which is reflected in the presence of genetic signals from different parts of Europe. We also find that women in our sample had a very high genetic diversity, which is reflected in the presence of genetic signals from different parts of Asia. This is an example of female-biased migration, which may have contributed to shape the modern European genetic landscape. In addition, we find that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study demonstrates the power of ancient DNA to study the history of Europe.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. The lagging strand of the genome is replicated by DNA polymerases that are anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the PCNA-pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart. These findings provide insights into the molecular basis of lagging strand DNA synthesis and the regulation of DNA polymerase recycling and exchange. The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules and replicated by RNA polymerases. In the laboratory, RNA polymerases have been used to synthesize RNA molecules, but the ability to replicate nucleic acids has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can also synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers and ribozymes. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the development of in vitro RNA life. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Copper is an essential micronutrient, but excess copper is toxic to cells. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to bind copper, but the role of the BGC in copper homeostasis has not been established. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is expressed in Aspergillus fumigatus, and that xan BGC-derived isocyanides bind copper. Copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC isocyanides were demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a potential target for the treatment of fungal infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a significant cause of crop failure and economic losses. The geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood, and the evolutionary impact of frost on plants is still poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the leaf-out timing of woody plants. We also show that the resistance strategies of plants to frost are strongly associated with the geographic distribution of frost events. These findings can be used to forecast the vulnerability of forests to frost damage under climate change. Our findings can be used to inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Using a Th17 transfer model of colitis, we found that Th17 cells could not induce disease in recipients lacking IFN-γ. In contrast, development of disease required the development of Th1-like cells from Th17 precursors and was dependent on the expression of both the transcription factors T-bet and Stat4. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms that give rise to these cells will provide insight into the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and other diseases in which Th17 cells play a pathogenic role. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical phenotypes. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring in the spinal cord, the site of motor neuron culture, after death. We now report a method to produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the ability of the pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum to colonize the vector. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. The findings also suggest that the gut microbiota of ticks may be a target for the development of novel strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is a key transition in the origin and diversification of birds. The earliest members of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) are critical for understanding how the modern avian bauplan evolved from long-tailed basal birds like Archaeopteryx. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian bauplan. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This finding is important for understanding the causes of past climate change and for predicting future climate change. It also has implications for the causes of the current warming. The feedback is likely to be positive in the current climate, but it is not clear whether it will remain positive in the future. This is an important question for climate research.

Vertebrates have evolved a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even to ultraviolet. The presence of these colors is often associated with a specific function, such as camouflage. In this study, we show that the presence of blue-green colors in vertebrates is not a coincidence, but rather a functional trait that has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

The role of N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modification of messenger RNA (mRNA) in regulating pluripotency and cancer stem cells has not been described. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which demethylated NANOG mRNA at an m6A residue in the 3′-UTR. Increased NANOG mRNA and protein expression, and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype, were induced by hypoxia in an HIF- and ALKBH5-dependent manner. Insertion of the NANOG 3′-UTR into a luciferase reporter gene led to regulation of luciferase activity by O2, HIFs, and ALKBH5, which was lost upon mutation of the methylated residue. ALKBH5 overexpression decreased NANOG mRNA methylation, increased NANOG levels, and increased the percentage of BCSCs, phenocopying the effect of hypoxia. Thus, HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression mediates enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for cancer treatment. The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment from the earliest pocket Bibles

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery interval at Meishan, China, based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle precedes the extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (PsycINFO Database Record

Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development and therapeutic intervention. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent in circulating variants, and it is thought to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We find that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein.

We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in health outcomes and mortality. (PsycINFO Database Record

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, and they are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We calculate these properties as a function of pressure, and we find that they decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. We also discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the development of a predictive theory of chemical phenomena under pressure. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in the climate system is poorly understood. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have already had a strong influence on the global fire regime, and that this will continue to affect the carbon cycle. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need for more research on the role of human ignitions and fire suppression. (PsycINFO Database Record

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is a major component of the squid’s own exoskeleton, and its provision to the symbiotic organ only at dusk is timed to coincide with the maturation of the organ. This timing is critical for the persistence of the symbionts, which are dependent on the catabolism of chitin for their own survival. Our results suggest that other hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their associated microbes through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in their symbionts’ habitat. This strategy may be particularly important for animals that live in complex, dynamic environments. (Read more)

The study of topics in text data is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We apply our method to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives of violent deaths. Many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We also identify the gender bias of our topics and show that our method can reveal gendered patterns in reporting about lethal violence. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to study the gendered nature of topics in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of the bacterium, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Instead, we find that the disease was likely introduced into Europe repeatedly, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y, from reservoirs in Asia. This finding challenges the traditional view of a single introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe. The sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting populations of at least 20 species of asteroids on the Northeast Pacific Coast. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of SSWD. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in nonasteroid echinoderms. This suggests that the virus is spread by the environment and/or by other echinoderms. The virus has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. This densovirus is therefore the most promising candidate disease agent responsible for asteroid mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. The settlement history of Madagascar is contentious, so we used the genomic data to test the hypothesis of a single settlement from Africa or Asia. We find that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the human population of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for understanding the human population of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their data is often not used in agricultural decision-making because it is difficult to integrate into quantitative models. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by the US Department of Agriculture, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is robust across crops and can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We also show that this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using crop expert assessments to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. This can help farmers and policy makers to better manage agricultural production and mitigate the impact of crop anomalies.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The Gaussian response of soil respiration to warming across all biomes suggests that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This study provides a unique perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was the result of a combination of natural variability and anthropogenic climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for informing the development of adaptation strategies.
