The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic (made by humans) quasicrystal was discovered in 1976 in a nuclear test. Here, we report the discovery of a second, older anthropogenic quasicrystal, in red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of these ancient quasicrystals demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed by transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions, and that the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems can be a by-product of human activity.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. A diiron cyclase is required in Rvi. gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. We also found that ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These results also suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a therapeutic target for reducing disease severity in later stages of EAE. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most severe in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades because of human activities. This increase is due to the fact that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm. We also find that the probability of drought has increased because of the increased likelihood of co-occurring warm and dry conditions. This finding is important because it suggests that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of the extremely warm and dry conditions that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought. The increased probability of such conditions is likely to continue in a warmer world. Thus, the 2012–2014 drought is a harbinger of what is to come.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and suggests that the forgetting process is a common target for autism-risk genes. This study also provides a new approach to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This approach may be useful for identifying the causal paths that lead to other complex disorders.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel, which result in bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions, and advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. Our results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the release of aggregates may be a promising therapeutic strategy. (Read more)

The bat is also the only mammal that has the ability to produce a unique class of lipid mediators, leukotrienes, which are potent mediators of inflammation. In this study, we identified a bat-specific protein, MTX, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in vitro and in vivo. We show that the one-carbon donor formate rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Finally, we show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer, and that targeting glycine import may be a promising strategy for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The earliest known aquatic angiosperms are poorly known. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This fossil material has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Contains figures.) read more

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating. This acceleration is caused by the same factors that cause the warming of the climate: greenhouse gas emissions from human activities. The acceleration is not a result of instrument or data issues. We estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y to be 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This implies global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate is a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure and reactivity of this intermediate. The results show that the α-aminoacrylate hydroxyl leaves the β-carbon, and the reaction proceeds through a transition state with the substrate indole bound in the active site. The results also show that the crystallographic water molecule is hydrogen bonded to the βLys ε-amino group, and that this water molecule is essential for the reaction. The results are used to understand why benzimidazole, an isostere of the natural substrate indole, does not react, while indole does. The results are also used to propose a mechanism for the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate with benzimidazole. The results are significant for understanding the mechanism of this and other β-elimination and replacement reactions catalyzed by enzymes that use pyridoxal-5′-phosphate as a cofactor. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease underscores the need for effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir, which is already in clinical use, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and also suggests that remdesivir may be effective against other coronaviruses. This is an important step toward the development of a treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is a major component of the squid’s own exoskeleton, and its provision to the symbiotic organ only at dusk is timed to coincide with the maturation of the organ. This timing is critical for the persistence of the symbionts, which are dependent on the catabolism of chitin for their own survival. Our results suggest that other hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their associated microbes through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in their symbionts’ habitat. This strategy may be particularly important for animals that live in complex, dynamic environments. (Read more)

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To infect human cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors and then fuse with the cell membrane. The spike (S) glycoproteins are the viral receptors and fusion-activating proteins, and they are cleaved sequentially during virus entry into cells. Here, we show that the first S cleavage is required for MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. This requirement for the first cleavage correlates with S conformations during entry, and the uncleaved MERS viruses are more infectious into human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they have sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, the first S cleavage may be a significant determinant of MERS-CoV virulence. Understanding how this cleavage contributes to MERS-CoV infection may help to develop more effective vaccines and therapeutics. (Read more)

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this system. In high-income countries, the majority of people eat meat and dairy products, which are responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in the food system could have a large impact on greenhouse gas emissions. This approach could be used to nudge people toward more sustainable diets. The approach is simple and requires no major changes to the food system. It could be implemented in any setting where people make meal choices. The approach could be used to nudge people toward more sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of six oncogene-expressing breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We also complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step toward understanding the role of the cell surface proteome in cancer. It also provides a resource for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic. We hope our paper will help inform the public debate about the future of elections in the United States.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has been characterized by a rapid spread and severe disease. The molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and the presence of this interface shows how ORF8 can mediate unique immune suppression and evasion activities. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis for the severity of the COVID-19 disease. This work also provides a foundation for the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. We describe a new approach to this problem. Instead of trying to find all the associations, we only look at the strongest ones. This approach is more powerful and more efficient.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vascular networks in vivo. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are critical for the development of the zebrafish eye. Here, we show that the zebrafish augmentor genes aug-α1, aug-α2, and aug-β are essential for iridophore patterning in the eye and in the body. We also show that the augmentor ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and in the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our findings provide insights into the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo and reveal a previously unknown role for augmentors in the development of the zebrafish eye. The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of these viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of YAP/TAZ in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been well established. However, the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that were extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies in the United States from 1992 to 2012. We find that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, and we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the design of clinical trials for ZIKV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral bleaching is a major stressor for coral reefs worldwide. The underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. We demonstrate that heat stress increased the metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which was compensated by the catabolic degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promoted the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Interpreting the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the absence of tumor suppression, intestinal tumors can lead to dysregulated immune responses and microbiome dysbiosis. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome can restore intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of JNK signaling in intestinal tumorigenesis and for developing strategies to control intestinal tumorigenesis and maintain host–microbe homeostasis. The timing of the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still debated. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a reduction in Southern Hemisphere winds. The Mount Takahe eruption series is the most distant volcanic event known to have caused stratospheric ozone depletion. Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our findings highlight the need for more attention to the importance of inland fisheries in global food security. (PsycINFO Database Record

However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is incapable of regenerating after injury, and the only known mechanism for regeneration in the adult mammalian brain is via grafting of embryonic tissue. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the MAPK signaling cascade, which is the major pathway for regeneration in the CNS of other organisms. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory neuron and is enhanced by disrupting calcium channels and elevating cAMP levels. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. Moreover, this study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work may also have implications for understanding the mechanisms of regeneration in the mammalian CNS in the context of neurodegenerative disease. This article is protected by copyright. Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create new combinations of genetic material. In humans and mice, hotspots of recombination are associated with genes, and the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9 is the best-characterized of the genes that it activates. Here, we describe the distribution of hotspots in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and show that they are distributed throughout the genome, with some interspersed among cold regions of low recombination. We also show that hotspots are more likely to terminate in exons than in introns. These results suggest that the distribution of hotspots in flowering plants may be conserved from yeast to humans. The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of brain regions that are functionally related. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. This approach may be particularly useful in the early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most prominent modification of mRNA. Here we show that 5′ NAD-RNA is also found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because it is also found on pre-mRNAs. The 5′ NAD-RNA cap is found on a subset of mRNAs that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD-RNA cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The 5′ NAD-RNA cap is a new modification of mRNA that deserves further investigation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. We hypothesized that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells may be associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes. These DNA-me differences were associated with glycemia in blood cells. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies are needed to determine the mechanisms of these persistent DNA-me differences and their potential for therapeutic intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with high morbidity and mortality. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) is a major crop worldwide, and its fruit is a popular food. The fruit of the closely related species Solanum pennellii is nearly devoid of all nitrogenous volatiles, while the fruit of S. lycopersicum and S. pimpinellifolium accumulate high amounts. Here we identify a gene essential for the production of these compounds in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of 2-substituted tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acids to the corresponding 2-substituted oximes, nitrosates, and nitriles. This pathway is unique to tomato and is not found in other species of the tomato clade. Understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds will improve our ability to improve the flavor of tomato fruit. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is a key driver of ecosystem functioning and biodiversity loss is expected to increase with global warming. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. We show that biodiversity loss will exacerbate the impacts of warming by reducing the resilience of ecosystems. This will have important implications for the functioning of the biosphere and the services it provides to society.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment and the direction of the animal’s head in a grid, head-direction (HD), and object-vector (OV) cell population, respectively. How these cell types are organized is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record simultaneously from large numbers of neurons in MEC and parasubiculum during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are strongly coupled, while border, HD, and OV cells tend to mix. These data suggest that grid cells are distinct from other cell types and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its connections to other brain regions. It also provides a framework for understanding the function of the MEC in navigation. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that FTs can be used as a tool to synchronize flowering of different species. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The precise nature of the pathology in this system is not fully understood. Here we show that the dopamine-containing nigral system has a more complex structure than previously recognized. We describe a specialized subsystem within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is formed by striosome–dendron bouquets. These formations are composed of striosomal fibers that project to striatum and dopamine-containing dendrites that project to the substantia nigra pars reticulata. We suggest that striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a more complete understanding of the structure and function of the dopamine-containing nigral system. It also provides a model for the study of other specialized subsystems within the brain. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for heart rate regulation and are characterized by specialized electrophysiological properties. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia that is associated with an increased risk of stroke. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for their automaticity. We show that STIM1 regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs by modulating store-operated and L-type Ca2+ currents. Our results reveal a previously unrecognized role for STIM1 in SANCs and suggest that targeting STIM1 may be a therapeutic strategy for treating atrial fibrillation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well established, its role in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well characterized. In this study, we demonstrate that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, in wild-type rice plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonate biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and jasmonates is mediated by jasmonates, which promote Si accumulation in rice plants. These results suggest that Si and jasmonates interact in rice defense against insect herbivory. This interaction may be a general phenomenon in plants. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important for the activation of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can lead to changes in the firing rates of neurons. These changes in firing rates can then be used to store information in a dynamic memory register. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biotechnologies. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for plant cell internalization and corresponding gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based biotechnologies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes, especially in the form of dissolved inorganic nutrients. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This could be accomplished by targeting the most important tributaries for nutrient management, which are likely to be the most vulnerable to nutrient loading.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We also find that the dynamics of the system are sensitive to the details of the environmental forcing, and that the system can exhibit a variety of behaviors, including oscillations and chaos, depending on the details of the forcing. These results have implications for understanding the dynamics of complex systems in general, and for understanding the behavior of chemical systems in particular.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic properties of cortical microcircuits, which can alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that NMDAR-Abs may be a therapeutic target for treatment of this disease. The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid climate change, and the Earth system response to this change is poorly understood. Here, we present a study of a major climate change that occurred during a glacial period. We show that a major climate change occurred ∼304 Ma, during a glacial period, and that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the Earth system response to abrupt warming. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for reducing deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce deforestation. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring and enforcement of certification requirements. This article is protected by copyright. The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This article is protected by copyright. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the acquisition of a new sex determination allele can produce additional axes of variation for sexual traits. These results have implications for understanding the evolution and maintenance of sex determination alleles. They also suggest that the modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics may be a general consequence of multiple interacting sex determination alleles. This modularity may be a key factor in the maintenance of sex determination alleles in populations. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple interacting sex determination alleles may also be a factor in the evolution of sex determination in species that have lost or gained sex determination alleles.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by reactive oxygen species and degraded by photoinduced decomposition into reactive intermediates. We show that the intracellular Fe pool is important for the redox cycling of bisretinoids and their photodegradation. The Fe chelator deferiprone reduced the oxidation of bisretinoids and their photodegradation in vitro and in vivo. These findings suggest that Fe levels in the retina are important for the redox cycling of bisretinoids and their photodegradation. This may have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and their evolution is fundamental to understanding how food webs have shaped the planet. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not only possible, but also common in nature. We also show that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of the prey itself. These findings help us understand how specialization has shaped the structure of food webs, and how it can be further modified in the future.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest hominin hand fossils are only 1.8 My old. Here we show that a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, was present in a 1.42-Myr-old hominin from Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. Mammalian cells have two SHMTs, one cytosolic and one mitochondrial. Cancer cells have been shown to up-regulate the mitochondrial isozyme, but the functional consequences of this up-regulation are not known. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in vitro and in vivo. Finally, we show that a deficiency in glycine import is a targetable metabolic defect of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type for which SHMT inhibition is highly effective. Collectively, these results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy. This finding has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study also shows that the use of covariate balancing generalized propensity score (CBGPS) weighting can be used to make causal inferences in observational studies. This approach is particularly useful in the context of this study given that the study is an observational study.

Modern farm machinery is responsible for the vast expansion of food production, but it has also increased the weight of farm vehicles, which has led to subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has propagated subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, which now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a 130-million-year-old footprint of a sauropod, a giant plant-eating dinosaur, in the Morrison Formation of Colorado
